content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}

Now given a task: Search for the most recent paper related to non-commutative geometry submitted by an author with the first name John. Provide the title and the abstract.  Please interact with https://arxiv.org/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To search for relevant papers, I should use the main search bar at the top. I need to enter the keywords "non-commutative geometry John" to find recent papers matching both the subject and author first name. The textbox to type is [4].
Action: Type [4]; non-commutative geometry John
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The initial query returned no results. The hints on the page suggest using the Author(s) field for better results and entering the name in "surname, forename" format. I should use Advanced Search to specify "non-commutative geometry" in the full-text search and "John" as the author's first name using the recommended format.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.3
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The advanced search form allows me to add multiple search terms and specify the fields. I should clear the previous text and add two separate search terms: one for the topic ("non-commutative geometry" in "All fields" or "Full text") and one for the author (in the Author(s) field), using the correct format for author search ("John" as forename, perhaps ", John" to search by forename).
Action: Type [12]; non-commutative geometry
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.4
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The current search for "non-commutative geometry" alone produced no results. I should refine the query to add an author filter. The "Refine query" button will likely allow me to specify the author in the proper format, separating search fields as recommended before.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.5
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: I need to use the advanced search form to add an author filter. The "Add another term +" button will let me insert a new field to specify the author's name (first name "John"). This is essential to properly fulfill the task instructions.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.6
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: There's a new search term row with a textbox [15] and a dropdown [16] set to "Title" by default. To search by author, I need to change the dropdown [16] to "Author(s)" and then enter "John" in textbox [15].
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown next to the added search term field is open, showing options including "Author(s)". I need to select "Author(s)" as the field so I can specify "John" as the author for filtering.
Action: Click [16]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dropdown is now set to "Author(s)", so I should enter "John" in the textbox [15] to filter papers authored by someone with the first name John.
Action: Type [15]; John
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search query returned no results. This could be because there are no recent papers on non-commutative geometry by an author named John, or perhaps the author search term needs to be broadened. I should try another approach such as searching simply for non-commutative geometry and then filtering manually for authors with the first name John from the search results.
Action: Click [13]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The advanced search form is reset. To attempt a broader search and manually filter for authors named John, I should type "non-commutative geometry" in the first search term and submit the search to get a list of related papers.
Action: Type [12]; non-commutative geometry
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search still returned no results. This indicates that searching by "non-commutative geometry" in the title is too restrictive. I should try a broader search by selecting "All fields" instead of "Title" to locate any recent paper mentioning non-commutative geometry, and then filter relevant results for authors named John.
Action: Click [12]
Confidence: 0.97
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The search term is now set, but still limited to searching in the "Title" field. To broaden the search, I should change the search field from "Title" to "All fields" using the dropdown [13] before executing the search.
Action: Click [13]
Confidence: 0.98
Completion: 0.8

content.text:
Observation: please analyze the attached screenshot and give the Thought and Action. I've provided the tag name of each element and the text it contains (if text exists). Note that <textarea> or <input> may be textbox, but not exactly. Please focus more on the screenshot and then refer to the textual information.
[1]: "member institutions";	[2]: "Donate";	[4]: <input> "Search term or terms";	[5]: "Help";	[6]: "Advanced Search";	[7]: "All fields Title Author Abstract Comments Journal reference ACM classification MSC classification Report number arXiv identifier DOI ORCID arXiv author ID Help pages Full text", "Field to search";	[8]: <button> "Search";	[9]: "Login";	[10]: "Search v0.5.6 released 2020-02-24";	[11]: "Simple Search";	[12]: <input> "";	[13]: "TitleAuthor(s)AbstractCommentsJournal referenceACM classificationMSC classificationReport numberarXiv identifierCross-list categoryDOIORCIDarXiv author IDAll fields";	[14]: <button> "Add another term +";	[15]: <button> "Search";	[21]: "allastro-phcond-matgr-qchep-exhep-lathep-phhep-thmath-phnlinnucl-exnucl-thphysicsquant-ph";

content:
Thought: The dropdown menu for search fields is open and "All fields" is visible at the bottom. Selecting "All fields" will ensure the search is as broad as possible and more likely to return papers, from which I can then manually look for authors named John.
Action: Click [13]
Confidence: 0.99
Completion: 0.85
